The city manager or her designee shall exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purpose and provisions of this chapter, including, but not limited to, the following powers: (1) To investigate the dwellings in the city in order to determine which dwellings, buildings, or structures therein constitute a nuisance, as defined herein; (2) To administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses, and to receive evidence; (3) To enter upon premises for the purposes of making examinations, provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; (4) To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as she deems necessary to carry out the purposes of the ordinances; and (5) To delegate any of her functions and powers under this chapter to such officers and agents as she may designate. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-9. - Request to investigate. Whenever a request is filed with the public officer by a public authority or by as least five residents of the municipality charging that any dwelling, building, structure, or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the city manager shall make an investigation or inspection of the dwelling, building, structure, or property. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-10. - Notice to abate. If the city manager's investigation or inspection identifies that any dwelling, building, structure, or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the city manager shall notify the responsible person creating, keeping, maintaining or permitting the same to abate the nuisance within ten days. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-11. - Issuance of complaint and summons. (1) If the nuisance is not abated following the notice required in section 38-9 or if adequate arrangements have not been made to abate the nuisance, the city manager may issue a complaint in rem and summons to the responsible person creating, keeping, maintaining or permitting the same to appear in municipal court or court of competent jurisdiction which shall be jurisdiction to hear and determine the existence of such nuisance, and if found to exist, to order its abatement. (2) The complaint shall identify the subject real property by appropriate street address and official tax map reference, identify the interested parties, state with particularity the factual basis for the action, and contain a statement of the action sought by the city manager or her designee to abate the alleged nuisance. Interested parties shall be: (1) property owner, (2) those parties having filed a notice in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-3-9, (3) any other party having an interest in the property whose identity and address are reasonably ascertainable from the records of the city or the records maintained in the county courthouse or by the clerk of court, and (4) persons in possession of the property. (3) The summons shall notify the interested parties, as defined herein, that a hearing will be held before a municipal court or court of competent jurisdiction at a fixed time and date. Such hearing shall be held no less than 15 days or more than 45 days after the filing of the summons and complaint in the court. The interested parties shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and lace fixed for hearing. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-12. - Service of notice, complaints and summons. (1) Complaints issued by the city manager pursuant to this chapter shall be served in the following manner. At least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing, the city manager shall mail copies of the complaint by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, to all interested parties whose identities and addresses are reasonably ascertainable. Copies of the complaint shall also be mailed by first-class mail to the property address to the attention of the occupants of the property, if any, and shall be posted on the property within three business days of filing the complaint and at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. (2) For interested parties whose mailing address is unknown, a notice stating the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be published in the newspaper in which the sheriffs advertisements appear in such county once a week for two consecutive weeks prior to the hearing. (3) A notice of lis pendens shall be filed in the office of the clerk of superior court of Habersham County at the time of filing the complaint in the appropriate court. Such notice shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. (4) Orders and other filings made subsequent to service of the initial complaint shall be served in the manner provided in this section on any interested party who answers the complaint or appears at the hearing. Any interested party who fails to answer or appear at the hearing shall be deemed to have waived all further notice in the proceedings. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-13. - Court hearing and abatement order. (1) A finding by any governmental health department, health officer, city manager, city police officer, or building official that any property, dwelling, building or structure is a health or safety hazard shall constitute a prima facie evidence that such property and/or person is in violation of this chapter. (2) If the court judge finds that that any dwelling, building, structure, or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the interested parties that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing an order: (a) If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation and, if applicable, to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or (b) If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure in order to bring into full compliance with applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building, or structure and all debris from the property. (c) For purposes of this section, the court shall make its determination of "reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure" without consideration of the value of the land on which the structure is situated; provided, however, that the costs of the preparation necessary to repair, alter, or improve a structure may be considered. Income and financial status of the owner shall not be a factor in the court's determination. The present value of the structure and the costs of repair, alteration, or improvement may be established by affidavits of real estate appraisers with a Georgia appraiser classification as provided in Chapter 39A of Title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, qualified building contractors, or qualified building inspectors without actual testimony presented. Costs of repair, alteration, or improvement of the structure shall be the cost necessary to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violations in force in the jurisdiction. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-14. - Failure to comply with abatement order. If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair or demolish the dwelling, building, or structure, the city manager may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished. Such abatement action shall commence within 270 days after the expiration of time specified in the order for abatement by the owner. Any time during which such action is prohibited by a court order issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13 or any other equitable relief granted by a court of competent jurisdiction shall not be counted toward the 270 days in which such abatement action must commence. The city manager shall cause to be posed on the main entrance of the building, dwelling, or structure a placard with the following words: This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use and does not comply with the applicable codes or has been ordered secured to prevent its use in connection with drug crimes or constitutes an endangerment to public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful. It shall be unlawful for such placard to be mutilated or removed or for such building to be occupied until the required corrective action is taken. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-15. - Requirement to salvage material. If the city manager has the structure demolished, reasonable effort shall be made to salvage reusable materials for credit against the cost of demolition. The proceeds of any moneys received from the sale of salvaged materials shall be used or applied against the cost of the demolition and removal of the structure, and proper records shall be kept showing application of sales proceeds. Any such sale of salvaged materials may be made without the necessity of public advertisement and bid. The city manager and governing authority are relieved of any and all liability resulting from or occasioned by the sale of any such salvaged materials, including, without limitation, defects in such salvaged materials (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-16. - Costs of demolition are lien against the real property. (1) That the amount of the cost of demolition, including all court costs, appraisal fees, administrative costs incurred by the county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to grade of the real property after demolition, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. (2) The lien provided for in this section shall attach to the real property upon the filing of a certified copy of the order requiring repair, closure, or demolition in the office of the clerk of Habersham County Superior Court and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under subsection (c) of Code Section 41-2-12. The clerk of superior court shall record and index such certified copy of the order in the deed records of the county and enter the lien on the general execution docket. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property, except liens for taxes to which the lien shall be inferior, and shall continue in force until paid. (3) Upon final determination of costs, fees, and expenses incurred in accordance with this chapter, the city manager shall transmit to the appropriate county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer a statement of the total amount due and secured by said lien, together with copies of all notices provided to interested parties. The statement of the city manager shall be transmitted within 90 days of completion of the repairs, demolition, or closure. (4) It shall be the duty of the appropriate county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer, who is responsible or whose duties include the collection of municipal taxes, to collect the amount of the lien using all methods available for collecting real property ad valorem taxes, including specifically Chapter 4 of Title 48; provided, however, that the limitation of Code Section 48-4-78 which requires 12 months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. A county tax commissioner shall collect and enforce municipal liens imposed pursuant to this chapter in accordance with Code Section 48-5-359.1. The county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer shall remit the amount collected to the governing authority of the City of Demorest. (5) Enforcement of liens pursuant to this section may be initiated at any time following receipt by the county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer of the final determination of costs in accordance with this chapter. The unpaid lien amount shall bear interest and penalties from and after the date of final determination of costs in the same amount as applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes. An enforcement proceeding pursuant to Code Section 48-4-78 for delinquent ad valorem taxes may include all amounts due under this chapter. (6) The redemption amount in any enforcement proceeding pursuant to this section shall be the full amount of the costs as finally determined in accordance with this section together with interest, penalties, and costs incurred by the City of Demorest, county tax commissioner, municipal tax collector, or city revenue officer in the enforcement of such lien. Redemption of property from the lien may be made in accordance with the provisions of Code Sections 48-4-80 and 48-4-81. (7) The city may waive and release any such lien imposed on property upon the owner of such property entering into a contract with the city agreeing to a timetable for rehabilitation of the real property or the dwelling, building, or structure on the property and demonstrating the financial means to accomplish such rehabilitation. (8) Where the abatement action does not commence in the superior court, review of a court order requiring the repair, alteration, improvement, or demolition of a dwelling, building, or structure shall be by direct appeal to the superior court under Code Section 5-3-29. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-17. - Injunction. Any person affected by an order issued by the city manager may petition to the superior court for an injunction restraining the city manager from carrying out the provisions of the order and the court may, upon such petition, issue a temporary injunction restraining the city manager pending the final disposition of the cause; provided, however, that such person shall present such petition to the court within 15 days of the posting and service of the order of the city manager. De novo hearings shall be had by the court on petitions within 20 days. The court shall hear and determine the issues raised and shall enter such final order or decree as law and justice may require; provided, however, that it shall not be necessary to file bond in any amount before obtaining a temporary injunction under this section. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-18. - Immediate abatement. Whenever any condition shall exist which constitutes an immediate and grave hazard to public health and safety requiring immediate action, the condition may be abated or otherwise remedied summarily and without following the procedures set forth herein. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 38-19. - Appeal. Any person affected by an order of the municipal court pursuant to this chapter may appeal this order within 30 days by application for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Habersham County. The filing of the application of writ of certiorari shall not act as a stay of the municipal court order, however. (Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 11-10-2008)

div.head: Chapter 42 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 42-1. - Being under influence of intoxicating liquors. Any person being under the influence of intoxicating drink on the streets or at any other public place within the city shall be guilty of an offense. (Code 1955, § 79) State Law reference— Public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-12. Sec. 42-2. - Disorderly conduct. Any person who shall use loud, boisterous, obscene, or profane language, or who shall fight, quarrel, or make any unnecessary noise tending to disturb, or who shall be guilty of any other disturbing conduct within the corporate limits of the city shall be guilty of disorderly conduct and guilty of an offense. (Code 1955, § 80) State Law reference— Disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. Sec. 42-3. - Disturbing sounds. Any person who shall make or knowingly allow others on his premises to make any noise at night calculated to disturb the peace of the city or the rest and quiet of any citizen shall be guilty of an offense. (Code 1955, § 81) State Law reference— Disturbance of meeting, gathering or procession, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. Sec. 42-4. - Posting bills. Any person who shall post any bills or signs on any public or private buildings in the city without the owner's consent shall be guilty of an offense. (Code 1955, § 82) Sec. 42-5. - Firearms. No person shall shoot or discharge firearms, such as guns, pistols, or any other shooting instrument. This section shall not apply to members of the armed forces of the United States or the National Guard while engaged in official duties, to law enforcement officers while engaged in official duties, or to any person exercising the right of self-defense or the defense of others. (Code 1955, § 83) Sec. 42-6. - Interfering with public notices. Any person who shall be guilty of marking any figure upon any official notice of the city or who shall alter, tear, or in any way interfere with any legal or other public notice such as street signs, park signs, or other official notices of the city, shall be guilty of an offense. (Code 1955, § 84) Sec. 42-7. - Disturbing public gathering. It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any public gathering of people in the city at any place of worship, amusement, or other lawful gathering by any loud or boisterous talking, or by any disturbing or indecorous behavior, either within or without the building in which the assembly is being held. (Code 1955, § 89) State Law reference— Disturbance of meeting, gathering or procession, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. Sec. 42-8. - Throwing missiles; possession or discharge of fireworks. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to throw rocks, stones, or any heavy missile on the streets or alleys of the city. It shall also be unlawful to shoot or use any sling-shot, flip, or any other means of casting stones calculated to injure the person or property of any citizen on the streets or public places within the city. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to have in their possession for sale or distribution with in the city limits any firecrackers, Roman candles or any other species of fireworks. It shall also be unlawful for any person to discharge any fireworks in the streets, alleys, or any other property of the city. (Code 1955, § 90) Sec. 42-9. - Hitchhiking. It shall be unlawful for any person to flag, thumb, or in any other way stop or attempt to stop cars or trucks for the purpose of hitchhiking on public highway no. 15 (U.S. Highway 23), passing through the city, within 100 yards of the intersection of Georgia Street. (Code 1955, § 91) Sec. 42-10. - Curfew for minors. It is unlawful for any person under 18 years of age to loiter, idle, congregate or be in any public street, highway, alley, park or other public place between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. However, the provisions of this section do not apply to a minor: (1) Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian or an adult designated by the minor's parent or guardian. (2) On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian or an adult designated by the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; (3) In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; (4) Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; (5) Involved in an emergency. In this subsection, the term "emergency" means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life; (6) Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the township, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the township, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; (7) Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or (8) Who are married or have been married or have had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with law. (Code 1955, § 91) Sec. 42-11. - Creating a hazardous condition. It shall be unlawful for any person to create a hazardous or physically offensive condition by an act that serves no legitimate purpose. (Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 4-1-2014)

div.head: Chapter 49 - PERSONNEL
div.p: Sec. 49-1. - Personnel handbook. The city shall establish a personnel handbook for all municipal employees, which shall be entitled and referred to as the City of Demorest Employee Handbook. The manual shall be initially established by vote of the mayor and city council. Amendments and updates to the handbook following its initial enactment may be made by the city manager from time to time as required by federal and state laws and the needs of the city, however, the mayor and council shall retain the ultimate right to amend the personnel handbook in their discretion. In addition to other sections deemed necessary by the mayor and city council, the handbook shall include policies regarding equal employment opportunity and non-discrimination and non-harassment on the basis of age, color, disability, gender, genetic information, national origin, race, and any other protected characteristic provided by law in the context of employment opportunities. The handbook also shall specify a complaint procedure for employees to report allegations or concerns of discrimination or harassment, and shall prohibit retaliation against any employee for making such a report or otherwise engaging in protected activity. The city manager shall ensure that all employees and officials are provided a copy of the employee handbook. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 3-6-2012) Sec. 49-2. - Employment at will. The City of Demorest is an "at will" employer, and does not utilize a civil service system. This chapter, the provisions of the employee handbook, and any policies and procedures established by the city are intended to serve as guides for assisting in the administration of personnel policies and procedures and ensure compliance with state and federal employment and wage and hour laws, but shall not be binding on the city and can be amended, applied, interpreted, suspended, or terminated by the city in its discretion as set forth herein. Neither this chapter, the employee handbook, nor any other policies and procedures of the city relating to personnel, employment, or wages shall create a contractual or property interest or expectancy for employees of continued employment, benefits, pay, or employment conditions at any time. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 3-6-2012) Sec. 49-3. - Job descriptions. The city shall maintain job descriptions containing specifications for each position held by one or more municipal employee. Job descriptions shall describe the duties of the position, the qualifications necessary, the licenses required, the supervisor to whom the position reports, the expected salary range, the essential functions of each position, the physical and mental requirements necessary to perform the essential functions of each position, and such other information as is necessary to recruit effectively for each municipal position. Job descriptions and the specifications therein may be amended from time to time by the city council, pursuant to § 3.10(a) of the City Charter, and should be so amended in order to maintain up to date job descriptions. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 3-6-2012) Sec. 49-4. - Benefits. The city shall establish and provide for such benefits as it sees fit in order to attract and retain qualified individuals for its workforce. Information concerning the benefits available, including eligibility for benefits and the cost to employees, shall be found in the personnel manual. The city shall be authorized to contract with benefits providers for the purpose of providing insurance, retirement, pension plans, and other benefits deemed necessary by the mayor and city council. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 3-6-2012) Sec. 49-5. - Records. The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 3-6-2012) Sec. 49-6. - Equal employment opportunity. The city recognizes that each employee and applicant for employment is important to the successful functioning of city governmental operations. Therefore, it is the policy of the city to provide equal employment opportunities without regard to age, color, disability, gender, genetic information, national origin, race, veteran or familial status, or any other characteristic protected by law. This policy relates to all aspects of employment, including but not limited to recruitment, hiring, placement, promotion, demotion, discipline, compensation, transfer, layoff, recall from layoff, benefits, and all other aspects of employment by the city. The city also does not condone, and specifically prohibits, harassment of employees by other employees, supervisors, or officials on the basis of any of the above-referenced protected characteristics. In accordance with the Americans with Disabilities Act, the city will make reasonable accommodations for disabled employees and applicants for employment. The office of the city manager shall publicize this policy throughout the city's operational and employment areas by providing all employees and officials with a copy of the employee handbook and by such other means as is deemed necessary, so as to make it known to all officials and employees of the city. The office of the city manager shall also ensure that all employees and officials have access to posters published by the Department of Labor or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission regarding adherence by employers to statutes such as the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Drug Free Workplace Act of 1988, the Equal Pay Act of 1963, the Fair Labor Standards Act, and any other posters required by federal or state employment laws and subsequent enactments. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 3-6-2012) Sec. 49-7. - Administration. The city manager shall be responsible for administering the personnel policies and procedures contained in the City Charter, this chapter, and the employee handbook, and for maintaining all personnel files and records. As part of his/her duties, the city manager shall have the responsibility of making all decisions regarding hiring, firing and disciplining all non-department head employees. The mayor and council retain the authority for making hiring decisions regarding department heads pursuant to § 3.10(e) of the City Charter. Likewise, pursuant to this section of the City Charter, the city manager has authority for terminating or suspending department heads. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 3-6-2012)

div.head: Chapter 58 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); litter control, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq.; Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Hazard Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-60 et seq.
Sec. 58-1. - Violations. (a) Any person charged with a violation of any section or provision of this chapter shall be given a written notice and instructions from the office of the city as to the required remedy for such violation and shall be given 30 days to comply with the provisions of this chapter. Failure to comply with the requirements of such written notice and instructions of the city public works director or his designee shall result in the termination of services by the public works director or his designee and shall be an offense. (b) Reinstatement of city trash and garbage collection shall only be provided after the person has fully complied with all the provisions of this chapter. Sec. 58-2. - City responsible for sanitation services generally. (a) All garbage, trash, and refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed, and disposed of by the city, except as expressly provided in this chapter. (b) The city will collect refuse in accordance with a schedule as established from time to time by the city and kept on file in the office of the city clerk. (c) The following items, products, or materials will not be collected, and it shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to place such items, products, or materials in any refuse can or container for collection: rubber tires, acid, explosive material, flammable liquids, dangerous or corrosive material of any kind, building materials, paint cans containing paint, whether bagged or not, and hazardous waste. Sec. 58-3. - Collection days designated. Garbage, trash, and refuse shall be collected from the various premises in the city by the city once each week. Sec. 58-4. - Preparation and storage of garbage and refuse for collection. (a) Garbage and refuse shall be bagged in plastic bags and placed in garbage cans or containers approved by the public works director or his designee. Garbage cans or containers shall be placed adjacent to the sidewalk on the property owner's side of the sidewalk, or if no sidewalk exists, then adjacent to the curb or pavement on the main road or street fronting the property. Alleys shall not be considered main roads or streets. Garbage cans or containers shall not impede, obstruct, or divert either pedestrian or vehicular traffic or the flow of surface water and shall not block drains. (b) Grass trimmings, small shrubbery trimmings, pine needles, and similar vegetation shall not be bagged and shall be placed immediately adjacent to the sidewalk on the property owner's side of the sidewalk, or if no sidewalk exists, then adjacent to the curb or the pavement and shall not impede, obstruct, or divert either pedestrian or vehicular traffic or the flow of surface water or drains. (Ord. of 12-6-2016, § 2) Sec. 58-5. - Rates and charges. The owners of all premises receiving garbage service shall pay to the city the service charge established by the mayor and council. Such charge shall be due on the date stated on the bill. Failure to pay the bill may result in discontinuance of service. Sec. 58-6. - Depositing in street or public place. It shall be unlawful for any person to litter, throw, deposit, scatter, or otherwise cause to be placed or left upon any vacant or unoccupied lot or lots, along any street or sidewalk or other public place or private property within the city without the consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, any paper, wastes, rubbish, trimmings, limbs or garbage of any kind.

div.head: Chapter 62 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS, AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— General powers regarding streets, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); authority of municipalities to own, operate and maintain streets, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; street obstructions, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-10; municipal street administration, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; assessments for improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq.
Sec. 62-1. - Sidewalk repairs. If a property owner damages or destroys any portion of a sidewalk adjoining his property, the property owner must reimburse the city for its repair or reconstruction. Sec. 62-2. - Parks. No person shall throw paper or trash in the parks of the city or commit any act tending to injure said parks. No person shall allow or permit cattle, hens, pigs or other animals to graze, scratch, root, or otherwise injure the park. (Code 1955, § 66)

div.head: Chapter 66 - TAXATION
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 66-1—66-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS LICENSE[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Local business license taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-4 et seq.
Sec. 66-31. - Business license tax imposed. Except as to those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations excluded by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-16(a), and except as to those persons excluded by O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1: (1) There is hereby levied an annual occupation tax on those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations that have one or more locations or offices within the corporate limits of the city in the amount of $100.00. (2) There is hereby levied an annual occupation tax of $100.00 on those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with no location or office in the state if the business or practitioner: a. Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or b. Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located in the corporate limits of the city. State Law reference— Basis of occupation tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-10; licenses for out of state practioners, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7; licensing of real estate brokers and agents, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-17. Sec. 66-32. - Due date. The occupation tax levied by the provisions of this article shall be due and payable to the city annually within 30 days following January 1 of each year. In the event that any person commences business on or after January 1 in any year, the tax shall be due and payable to the city 30 days following the commencement of the business. Sec. 66-33. - Penalties and interest for late payment. (a) Should any occupation tax imposed by this article remain due and unpaid for 90 days from the due date of the tax, the person liable for the tax or fee shall be subject to and shall pay a penalty of ten percent of the tax or fee due. Such tax shall be considered delinquent if not paid within 90 days of the due date of the tax. (b) The person liable for the tax imposed by the provisions of this article shall pay to the city interest on delinquent occupation tax at a rate of 1½ percent per month. Sec. 66-34. - Civil fine for failure to pay. The municipal court shall impose a civil fine for failure to pay the occupation tax levied by the provisions of this article. Such a civil fine shall not exceed $500.00 and may be enforced by the contempt power of the court. Secs. 66-35—66-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - INSURANCE TAX
Sec. 66-61. - Insurers license fees. There is hereby levied for the year 1998, and for each year thereafter, an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the city in the amount of $25.00, until changed by ordinance or resolution of the council. For each separate business location in excess of one which is not covered by section 66-62, and which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the city, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of $25.00, until changed by ordinance or resolution of the council. For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. (Ord. of 12-2-1997, § 1) Sec. 66-62. - License fees for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. For each separate business location not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales offers, that solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, said insurer shall pay an additional license fee of $10.00, until changed by ordinance or resolution of the council, per location for the year 1998 and for each year thereafter. (Ord. of 12-2-1997, § 2) Sec. 66-63. - Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 1998, and for each year thereafter, an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the state in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 66-61. (Ord. of 12-2-1997, § 3) Sec. 66-64. - Gross premiums tax, all other insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 1998, and for each year thereafter, an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business within the state in an amount equal to 2.5 percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 66-61. (Ord. of 12-2-1997, § 4) Sec. 66-65. - Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in sections 66-61 and 66-62 shall be due and payable on the first day of each year.

div.head: Chapter 70 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES
div.p:
Sec. 70-1. - Uniform Rules of the Road adopted. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372—40-6-376, the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 and O.C.G.A. title 40, ch. 6 (O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.) are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited herein. Sec. 70-2. - Traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings. The location and existence of all traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings in place as of the adoption date of this Code are ratified and confirmed. Sec. 70-3. - Parking regulations. It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle, at any time, on any alley of nine feet or less in width within the city limits. (Code 1955, § 87) Sec. 70-4. - Speed zones. (a) Speed zones created: The following speed zones are established based upon the City's Authority pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183, as well as a completed engineering and traffic investigation related to the same: ON-SYSTEM
OFF SYSTEM
(b) School zones: For purposes of the above referenced school zones, school zone specific regulations shall be effective in the a.m. from 45 minutes prior to commencement time to 15 minutes after commencement time, and in the p.m. from 15 minutes prior to dismissal time to 45 minutes after dismissal time, all such school zones limited to school days only, time and commencement time, dismissal time, and school days to be determined by the Habersham County School System. (c) Signage: Signs for all on-system speed zones shall be erected and maintained by the Georgia Department of Transportation. Signs for all off-system speed zones shall be erected and maintained by the City of Demorest, Georgia. Signage for all speed zones shall be designed, located, and erected so as to comply with Georgia law. (d) Speed detection devices: It shall be permissible to use speed detection devices for speed zone enforcement in any of the above described speed zones. Speed detection devices include all those devices encompassed within Title 40, Chapter 14, Article II, of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. It shall not be permissible to use speed detection devices in areas not described as a speed zone above. (e) Unauthorized changes: Any unauthorized changes to this section shall cause this section to be void in its entirety. (f) Enforcement: Enforcement of this section shall be by any sworn law enforcement officer acting within his scope of duties and within his jurisdictional limits at the time of enforcement. Enforcement personnel for this ordinance shall include, but shall not be limited to, the Demorest Police Department, Habersham County Sheriff's Office, and the Georgia State Patrol. Ord. No. 2010-01, § 2, 1-5-1010)

div.head: Chapter 74 - UTILITIES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. of 6-16-2017(1) has been treated by the editor as superseding former Art. I, §§ 74-1—74-11, in its entirety. Former Art. I pertained to similar subject matter and derived from legislation included in 2007 codification and the following uncodified ordinances and provisions: Ord. No. 2012-04, § 1(Exh. A), 4-3-2012; Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1(Exh. A), 3-6-2012; Ord. of 6-17-2015, §§ 2—10. Section numbering of the provisions of Art. I has been amended by the editor to avoid conflicts.
Sec. 74-1. - Connection fees; water and sewer rates. Connection fees, water and sewer rates are as follows: CONNECTION FEES
*plus cost of meter WATER AND SEWER RATES
(Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 1(Exhs. A, B)) Sec. 74-2. - Application for water and sewer service. An applicant for water and sewer service shall complete an application in person at City Hall in Demorest. Credit checks shall not be conducted before service is provided to the applicant. A security deposit of $100.00 shall be required when the application is completed, and the applicant shall submit to the city a government issued photo identification. Leased or rental property requires that applicant/tenant furnish an executed lease agreement. The user agrees to all terms set forth in the city's user agreement by executing the application. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 2) Sec. 74-3. - City's duties. The city shall install and maintain a service line from the city's distribution line to the property line immediately adjacent to the property to be served. The city may connect to properties not adjacent to the city's lines upon payment of reasonable costs for extension of the city's water and/or sewer line to render service, but this determination shall be at the city's sole discretion. The city's meter may be installed at or near the property line or upon the property to be served within three feet of the property line at the city's discretion in accord with reasonable engineering practices. The city may refuse service if the lines upon the property to be served or the piping located thereon are installed or exist in such manner as to prevent cross connections or back flow. The city shall exercise good faith efforts to notify all customers by radio, the local newspaper, Nixle, website, or social media of any anticipated interruptions of service. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 3) Sec. 74-4. - User's responsibility and duties. Water furnished by the city shall be used for consumption by the user and the user's household and employees only. The user shall not sell water to any other person nor permit any other person or user to consume water provided by the city. Water provided by the city shall not be used for irrigation, fire protection, or other purposes, except if water is available in sufficient quantity without interfering with regular domestic consumption in the area served. If a meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a user, then a suitable location shall be provided by the user that is unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. The user shall furnish and maintain a private cut off value on the user's side of the meter. The user's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the user at the user's expense in a safe and efficient manner and in accord with regulations promulgated by the State of Georgia and any other applicable regulation. All applicants and users must offer proof that any private well located upon the property is not physically connected to the lines of the city's water system. All applicants and users covenant and agree not to permit the connection of any private wells over which the applicant/user has control to be connected to the city's water system. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 4) Sec. 74-5. - Access to premises and extensions of systems. Authorized agents and personnel of the city shall have access at all times to the user's premises for the limited purposes of installing or removing city property, inspecting piping, reading and testing meters, or for other purposes related to the city's water service and facilities and the city's sewer services and facilities. Extensions to the city's water or sewer system shall be made only when the user shall grant or convey or cause to be granted or conveyed to the city a permanent easement and right-of-way to cross property traversed by city water lines and sewer lines. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 5) Sec. 74-6. - Change of occupancy. The user shall provide notice in person or in writing at City Hall of Demorest to discontinue water and/or sewer service or to change occupancy. The outgoing user shall be responsible for all water consumed and sewer discharged up to the date of departure or the date specified for departure, whichever last occurs. The new occupant shall apply for utility service prior to occupying the premises. Any failure to notify the city shall render the new occupant responsible for the water consumed and sewer discharged since the last meter reading. The failure to notify the city to close an account may result in additional water use charges. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 6) Sec. 74-7. - Meter reading; billings; collecting. Bills to users of water and sewer service shall be mailed on such day or days each month as may be determined by the city. Bills shall be paid at City Hall in Demorest or at such other location designated by the city. A failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent bills from becoming delinquent or relieve the user from payment. The failure of water and/or sewer users to pay charges duly imposed shall result in the automatic imposition of the following fees: (1) Nonpayment on the due date will be subject to a fee of ten percent of the delinquent account; (2) Nonpayment after two billing cycles shall result in water being disconnected from the user's property. Payment is not authorized in the field. If a disconnect work order is issued, then the disconnection crew lacks the authority to accept payment in the field; (3) The city may require an additional deposit to insure proper payment of water and sewer charges; (4) Vacant or unoccupied property may continue to receive water and sewer service. However, minimum bills and charges for water used shall continue to be due. If service is terminated, then any vacant or unoccupied property shall be treated as a new user and must apply for service and pay applicable fees; (5) A $35.00 fee shall be charged for all returned checks, which may also result in the disconnection of service; and (f) A service that has been disconnected for nonpayment shall be restored only after the outstanding invoice has been paid in full, a security deposit approved by the mayor and city council has been paid, and a reconnection fee of $40.00 paid by cash, credit card or certified funds. All disconnected accounts paid after 2:00 p.m. shall be reconnected the next business day. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 7) Sec. 74-8. - Billing for multi-unit buildings. (a) All existing multi-unit buildings (including but not limited to apartments, townhomes, condominiums, and commercial buildings containing multiple tenant spaces) with a utility-owned master meter shall be billed a monthly base rate that is equivalent to the established monthly base rate for a single unit times the number of units within the building as indicated by planning and zoning approved plans, whether occupied or not, plus any excess water used above the calculated minimum charge. Any new multi-unit buildings (including but not limited to apartments, townhomes, condominiums, and commercial buildings containing multiple tenant spaces) shall have individual water utility owned meters on each unit or sub-unit meters owned and managed by the property owner with a utility owned master meter that bills for water service based on volume of use for each customer. If existing city-owned rights-of-way are not suitable for the installation of individual meters, the following conditions must be met for the installation of individual meters on private property: (1) The owners of all individual living units shall grant easements to the city for meter installation within ten feet of the curb line of existing rights-of-way for water mains. (2) The easements shall comply with water department specifications. (3) The owner of all individual living units shall indemnify the city against all damage claims resulting from the installation, maintenance of and access to meters on private property. (4) The owner of each individual living premises shall acknowledge in writing that water lines between the meter and living unit and the living unit interior plumbing will be maintained by the owner and that cutoff valves must be installed by the owner on the discharge side of the meter box at or near the property line. (5) If required in lieu of dedicated streets, a 20-foot right-of-way centered on the water main shall be conveyed to the city, except that the director of the water and sewer department may accept a narrower right-of-way if obstructions require less than 20 feet. (b) If an owner of multi-family dwelling or complex fails to install a separate water meter for each individual dwelling unit, the water service to such customer at that address shall be discontinued until the property owner complies with the requirements of this section. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 8) Sec. 74-9. - Suspension of service. (a) If water and/or sewer service is discontinued and all outstanding invoices are paid, then the security deposit shall be refunded to the user by the city. If the service is discontinued for nonpayment of invoices, then the security deposit shall be applied by the city toward the account balance. Any balance of the security deposit shall be refunded to the user according to the policy set in the user agreement. However, if the security deposit is insufficient to pay the outstanding invoice then the city may proceed to collect the balance from the user. Services disconnected for nonpayment of bills shall be restored only after the outstanding invoice is paid in full. Any user who enters the meter box and turns on the service shall be in violation of this article and subject to applicable penalties. (b) The city reserves the option to discontinue service without notice for the following reasons: (1) To prevent fraud or abuse; (2) Past due accounts; (3) Willful disregard of the city's rules and regulations; (4) Emergency repairs; (5) Insufficient water supply due to circumstances beyond the city's control; (6) Legal processes; (7) Direction of public authorities; or (8) Strike, riot, fire, flood, unavoidable accident. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 9) Sec. 74-10. - Complaints; adjustments. If the user believes a bill to be in error, then the user shall present the claim, in person, to City Hall before the bill becomes delinquent. If the claim is made after the bill becomes delinquent, then any such claim shall not be effective to prevent discontinuance of the service. A user may pay a bill under protest, and such payment shall not prejudice the claim. The city shall make a special meter reading at the request of a user for a fee of $5.00. If the special reading discloses that the meter was misread, then no charge shall be due, and any payment shall be refunded to the user. A water meter shall be tested for the production of a data log at the user's request upon payment to the city in the amount of $30.00. If the meter is found to over-register beyond three percent of the correct volume, then no charge shall be due from the user, and any charge shall be refunded to the user. If the seal of a meter is broken by someone other than the city's authorized agent or employee or if the meter fails to register correctly or if stopped by any cause, then the user shall pay an amount estimated based upon the record of previous bills to the location and/or other proper data. Disputed bills shall be paid in full, and a request for adjustment shall be submitted to the city clerk. An adjustment to the bill will be determined according to internal policy. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 10) Sec. 74-11. - Reserved. Sec. 74-12. - Property liens on unpaid water accounts. Where a water customer's account is in arrears and the account is at a property owned or which has a real property interest held by the water customer, such water account may be collected by a lien on the real property. (Ord. of 7-14-2011, § 1) Sec. 74-13. - Perfection of lien; notice. Any lien created by such an account in arrears shall be deemed an exercise of the city's police powers. The lien shall arise automatically when a water bill is due and unpaid and the account covers the property where the water bill is in arrears. Such lien is exempt from the general notice and recording provisions of O.C.G.A. § 42-2-1 and § 42-2-2. (Ord. of 7-14-2011, § 1) Sec. 74-14. - Water lien priority. Any lien created pursuant to this article shall have the same priority as liens for ad valorem taxes. (Ord. of 7-14-2011, § 1) Sec. 74-15. - Prohibited uses. (a) Fraudulent use. Evidence of the existence of a bypass, the bypassing of water around meters, or the unauthorized piping or selling of water, or any other use of unmetered water except for fire extinguishing purposes shall be deemed fraudulent use. (b) Tampering. No person shall tamper with a city water meter or in any manner impede the city's ability to determine the accurate consumption from said meter. (c) Unauthorized reconnection. No person shall reconnect or turn on any water connection where the water connection has been disconnected by the city for nonpayment of water bills or for any other purpose. (d) Damage to system. No person shall damage, destroy, deface, impair the function of, or otherwise vandalize any portion of the city water supply system. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 11) Sec. 74-16. - Penalties. (a) Any person who commits any act prohibited or fails to do any act required by this article and these regulations shall, upon citation and conviction in a court of competent jurisdiction, be subject to a fine and possible incarceration in accord with Demorest City Charter section 4.13 and Demorest City Charter section 4.13 (c) as amended February, 2015. (b) Where an offense or violation continues from day to day, each day's continuance thereof shall be deemed a separate offense. (c) The penalties provided in this section an exclusive remedy, and shall not prohibit the city from pursing any other civil or criminal remedies authorized by this Code, state law of federal law. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 11) Sec. 74-17. - Enforcement. This article may be enforced by the police department for the City of Demorest or other duly authorized law enforcement officer/. (Ord. of 6-6-2017(1), § 11) Secs. 74-18—74-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER CONSERVATION
Sec. 74-41. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Business using high volumes of water means a water customer receiving more than 50,000 gallons of water per day from the city water system. Essential services means health care, sanitation, cooking needs and fire protection. Inside city means inside the city limits. Level I means the public shall be notified to begin voluntary water conservation measures through the news media and by publishing a notice in the county legal organ. The public notice shall be advisory and request water customers to cease unnecessary outside water usage. Level II means there shall be no outside water usage during days and hours or as determined by the mayor upon recommendation by the utilities director and affirmed by the city council. The city water and sewer department shall approve all use of the city distribution system to fill a tank truck or to directly fill a swimming pool from a fire hydrant. The standard used by the water and sewer department to exercise this discretion shall be to protect: (1) Either storage volumes or system pressures from dropping below the levels stated in section 74-44; and (2) The water supply to assure that public health and safety are not imminently threatened. Level III means there shall be no outside water usage during days and hours determined by the mayor upon recommendation by the utilities director and affirmed by the city council. Businesses using high volumes of water may be put under significant restrictions by the utilities director. When exercising this discretion, the utilities director shall consider: (1) The effect that a high-volume user has on causing the level mentioned in section 74-44; (2) Whether limiting a business' hours or days of operation will allow water levels to exceed the levels mentioned in section 74-44; and (3) The increased water supply generated by any restrictions to best promote public health and safety. Level IV means all outdoor water use shall be banned. Water may be rationed for essential purposes only. Commercial and industrial users shall be restricted in accordance with a plan adopted by the utilities director and mayor and affirmed by the city council. Low pressure means less than 20 pounds per square inch (psi). Outdoor water usage means lawn and garden watering, noncommercial car washing, filling of private swimming pools, noncommercial pressure washing of building exteriors, sidewalks, or driveways, or similar types of nonessential outdoor water usage as determined by the city council. Outside city means outside the city limits. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 1) Sec. 74-42. - Applicability. This article shall apply to all users of the city water system, whether inside the city or outside the city. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 2) Sec. 74-43. - Purpose and public notification. (a) The purpose of this article shall be to provide for emergency procedures to prevent threats to public health and safety arising from periods of water shortage and drought and to prevent acts that cause or can be reasonably expected to cause significant imminent harm to limited water resources. (b) The public shall be notified that this article is in effect and which level is being implemented through the news media and by publishing a notice in the county legal organ at least 24 hours prior to the particular level being implemented. (c) Each level may be implemented by the mayor upon recommendation of the utilities director, subject to approval, rescission, or modification by the city council at its next regular or called meeting. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 3) Sec. 74-44. - Implementation—Level I. Level I shall be implemented if the city exceeds 90 percent of its permitted water withdrawal amount or maximum safe production level for one day or if low pressure or loss of service is experienced, or if directed by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources, or as the result of any other applicable state or federal mandate. Level I shall remain in effect until all factors are relieved and shall cease when the mayor determines that an adequate supply to fulfill public needs exists. The mayor's decision shall be made upon recommendation of the utilities director and shall be subject to being approved or modified by the city council at its next meeting. The public shall be notified of the termination of level I through the news media and notices on customer invoices. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 4) Sec. 74-45. - Same—Level II. Level II shall be implemented if level I is not sufficiently effective in restoring water levels above the levels described in section 74-44, or if directed by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources, or as the result of any other applicable state or federal mandate. Level II shall remain in effect until the factors that invoked level I are relieved for two weeks from the last date on which one or more factors occurred. When level II is withdrawn, level I shall be reimplemented. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 5) Sec. 74-46. - Same—Level III. Level III shall be implemented if level II fails to prevent loss of service, or if directed by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources, or as the result of any other applicable state or federal mandate. Level III shall remain in effect until loss of service ceases. When level III is withdrawn, level II measures shall be reimplemented. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 6) Sec. 74-47. - Same—Level IV. Level IV shall be implemented when level III fails to prevent loss of service, or if directed by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources, or as the result of any other applicable state or federal mandate. Level IV shall remain in effect until loss of service ceases. When level IV is withdrawn, level III measures shall be reimplemented. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 7) Sec. 74-48. - Extreme cases. (a) In extreme cases of loss of service, the utilities director may authorize closing valves in the water distribution system. When exercising this discretion, the utilities director shall: (1) Make water available to private consumers from fire hydrants that are equipped to dispense water to the consumers' private containers; (2) Fully consider the needs of medical facilities; and (3) If possible, avoid the interruption of fire protection. (b) When determining "extreme cases," the utilities director shall consider: (1) Loss of service; (2) Available water supply; and (3) The threat posed to public health and safety by continued water usage. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 8) Sec. 74-49. - Water conservation surcharges. (a) Violation of level II. (1) Private water consumers shall pay a surcharge of $200.00 and/or have the water supply terminated. Water supply shall not be restored until payment of the surcharge and a reconnection fee of $20.00 for inside-city water customers or $40.00 for outside-city water customers. (2) Businesses using high volumes of water shall pay a surcharge of $500.00 and have the water supply terminated. Water supply shall not be restored until payment of the surcharge and a reconnection fee of $20.00 for inside-city water customers and $40.00 for outside-city water customers. (b) Violation of level III. (1) Private water consumers shall pay a surcharge of $400.00 and have the water supply terminated. Water supply shall not be restored until payment of the surcharge and a reconnection fee of $20.00 for inside-city water customers and $40.00 for outside-city water customers. (2) Businesses using high volumes of water shall pay a surcharge of $2,500.00 and have the water supply terminated. Water supply shall not be restored until payment of the surcharge and a reconnection fee of $20.00 for inside-city water customers or $40.00 for outside-city water customers. (c) Violation of level IV . The violator shall pay a surcharge of $2,500.00 and have the water supply terminated. Water supply shall not be restored until payment of the surcharge and a reconnection fee of $20.00 for inside-city water customers or $40.00 for outside-city water customers. (d) Procedures. (1) The utilities director shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this section by discontinuance of water service in the event any person violates the provisions of this section after receiving oral or written notice of the violation from the city. (2) Whenever the utilities director determines that a person is violating or has violated any provision of this section and that the violation of this section endangers the public health, safety or general welfare of the community, the utilities director shall have the power and authority to immediately terminate that person's water service. (3) Any person aggrieved by having the water supply terminated by the utilities director shall have the right to appeal the termination to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken within three days from the date of the termination by notifying the city manager in writing and specifying the grounds of appeal. The city council shall fix a date and time for the hearing of the appeal within two days after the receipt of the notice of appeal, shall, after due notice to the parties at interest, have a hearing on the appeal within five days of the date the notice of appeal was received by the city, and shall decide same within three days of the date of the hearing. (4) If an appeal is made, then the utilities director shall have the power and authority to reinstate the water supply until the council renders a decision in order to avoid undue hardship, if the utilities director is reasonably assured that the violation for which the water supply was terminated will not continue. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 9) Sec. 74-50. - Penalties. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of this article. The violation of any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00, by imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. of 8-1-2006, § 10) Sec. 74-51. - Restriction on outdoor water of landscape. Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs or other plants may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: (1) Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites and turkeys; producing plants, trees fowl or animals; or for the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs and apiarian products, or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; (2) Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or storm water in compliance with applicable city ordinances and state guidelines; (3) Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; (4) Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed waste water; (5) Watering personal food gardens; (6) Watering new and replanted plant, seed or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sport turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; (7) Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; (8) Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; (9) Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; (10) Watering horticultural crops for sale, resale or installation; (11) Watering athletic fields, golf courses or public turf grass recreational areas; (12) Installation, maintenance or calibration of irrigation systems; or (m) Hydroseeding. (Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 1-4-2011) Sec. 74-52. - Enforcement (a) No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in this article. (b) The city manager shall be the enforcement authority for this article. The city manager may also authorize other departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement. (c) Criminal and alternative penalties. Any violation of this article may be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the municipal court pursuant to Charter section 4.13 or by any other legal means as set forth in the Code. (Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 1-4-2011) Secs. 74-53—74-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1, adopted Nov. 10, 2008, amended the code by adding provisions numbered as §§ 74-51—74-62. In order to avoid conflicts in section numbering the editor has renumbered the provisions added as herein set out.
Sec. 74-81. - Short title. This article shall be known as the "Identity Theft Prevention Program." (Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 74-82. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to comply with 16 CFR § 681.2 in order to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft. (Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 74-83. - Definitions. For purposes of this article, the following definitions apply: [3] City means the City of Demorest, Georgia. Covered account means: (1) An account that a financial institution or creditor offers or maintains, primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, that involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions, such as a credit card account, mortgage loan, automobile loan, margin account, cell phone account, utility account, checking account, or savings account; and (2) Any other account that the financial institution or creditor offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the financial institution or creditor from identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation, or litigation risks. Credit means the right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and defer payment therefor. Creditor means any person who regularly extends, renews, or continues credit; any person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal, or continuation of credit; or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the decision to extend, renew, or continue credit and includes utility companies and telecommunications companies. Customer means a person who has a covered account with a creditor. Identity theft means a fraud committed or attempted using identifying information of another person without authority. Person means a natural person, a corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency, trust, estate, partnership, cooperative, or association. Personal identifying information means a person's credit card account information, debit card information, bank account information, and drivers' license information, and for a natural person, includes his/her Social Security number, mother's birth name, and date of birth. Red flag means a pattern, practice, or specific activity that indicates the possible existence of identity theft. Service provider means a person that provides a service directly to or for the benefit of the city. (Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1, 11-10-2008) Footnotes: --- (3) --- Other than "city" and "personal identifying information", definitions provided in this section are based on the definitions provided in 16 CFR § 681.2.
Sec. 74-84. - Findings. (a) The city is a creditor pursuant to 16 CFR § 681.2 due to its provision or maintenance of covered accounts for which payment is made in arrears. (b) Covered accounts offered to customers for the provision of city services include water sewer, sanitation and fire (outside the city limits only) services. (c) The city's previous experience with identity theft related to covered accounts is as follows: identification of customers using false names or false social security numbers. (d) The processes of opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account, and making payments on such accounts, have been identified as potential processes in which identity theft could occur. (e) The city limits access to personal identifying information to those employees responsible for or otherwise involved in opening or restoring covered accounts or accepting payment for use of covered accounts. Information provided to such employees is entered directly into the city's computer system and is not otherwise recorded. (f) The city determines that there is a low risk of identity theft occurring in the following ways: (1) Use by an applicant of another person's personal identifying information to establish a new covered account; (2) Use of a previous customer's personal identifying information by another person in an effort to have service restored in the previous customer's name; (3) Use of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment by a customer to pay such customer's covered account or accounts; and (4) Use by a customer desiring to restore such customer's covered account of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment. (Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 74-85. - Process of establishing a covered account. (a) As a precondition to opening a covered account with the city, each applicant shall provide the city with personal identifying information of the customer including a valid government issued identification card containing a photograph of the customer or, for customers who are not natural persons, a photograph of the customer's agent opening the account, or such other identifying information that the city deems sufficient to establish identify. Such applicant shall also provide any information necessary for the department providing the service for which the covered account is created to access the applicant's consumer credit report, should city decide to implement such policy. Such information shall be entered directly into the city's computer system and shall not otherwise be recorded. (b) Each account shall be assigned an account number. The city may utilize computer software to encrypt account numbers. (Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 74-86. - Access to covered account information. (a) Access to the system containing customer accounts shall be password protected and shall be limited to authorized city personnel. (b) Such password(s) shall be changed by the city manager on a regular basis, shall be at least eight characters in length and shall contain letters and numbers. (c) Any unauthorized access to or other breach of customer accounts is to be reported immediately to the city manager and the password changed immediately. (d) Personal identifying information included in customer accounts is considered confidential and any request or demand for such information shall be immediately forwarded to the city manager and the city attorney. (Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 74-87. - Credit card payments. (a) In the event that credit card payments that are made over the Internet are processed through a third-party service provider, such third-party service provider shall certify that it has complied with FTC regulations and has an adequate identity theft prevention program in place that is applicable to such payments. (b) All credit card payments made over the telephone or the city's website shall be entered directly into the customer's account information in the computer database. (c) Account statements and receipts for covered accounts shall include only the last four digits of the credit or debit card or the bank account used for payment of the covered account. (Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1, 11-10-2008) Sec. 74-88. - Sources and types of red flags. All employees responsible for or involved in the process of opening a covered account, restoring a covered account, or accepting payment for a covered account shall check for red flags as indicators of possible identity theft and such red flags may include: (1) Alerts from consumer reporting agencies, fraud detection agencies, or service providers. Examples of alerts include: a. A fraud or active duty alert that is included with a consumer report; b. A notice of credit freeze in response to a request for a consumer report; c. A notice of address discrepancy provided by a consumer reporting agency; d. Indications of a pattern of activity in a consumer report that is inconsistent with the history and usual pattern of activity of an applicant or customer, such as: i. A recent and significant increase in the volume of inquiries; ii. An unusual number of recently established credit relationships; iii. A material change in the use of credit, especially with respect to recently established credit relationships; or iv. An account that was closed for cause or identified for abuse of account privileges by a financial institution or creditor. (2) Suspicious documents. Examples of suspicious documents include: a. Documents provided for identification that appear to be altered or forged; b. Photographs or physical descriptions that are inconsistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer; c. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with information provided by the applicant or customer; d. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with readily accessible information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor, such as a signature card or a recent check; or e. An application that appears to have been altered, forged, destroyed, or reassembled. (3) Suspicious personal identification. Examples of suspicious identifying information include: a. Personal identifying information is inconsistent with external information sources used by the financial institution or creditor. For example: i. The address does not match any address in the consumer report; or ii. The Social Security Number (SSN) has not been issued, or is listed on the Social Security Administration's Death Master File. b.
